    Discovery of N-(Pyridin-4-yl)-1,5-naphthyridin-2-amines as Potential Tau Pathology PET Tracers for Alzheimer’s Disease

    Abstract

    A mini-HTS on 4000 compounds selected using 2D fragment-based similarity and 3D pharmacophoric and shape similarity to known selective tau aggregate binders identified N-(6-methylpyridin-2-yl)quinolin-2-amine 10 as a novel potent binder to human AD aggregated tau with modest selectivity versus aggregated β-amyloid (Aβ). Initial medicinal chemistry efforts identified key elements for potency and selectivity, as well as suitable positions for radiofluorination, leading to a first generation of fluoroalkyl-substituted quinoline tau binding ligands with suboptimal physicochemical properties. Further optimization toward a more optimal pharmacokinetic profile led to the discovery of 1,5-naphthyridine 75, a potent and selective tau aggregate binder with potential as a tau PET tracer.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a chronic neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia among the elderly population, is characterized by progressive cognitive impairment including memory loss, compromised executive function, behavioral symptoms, and loss of ability for self-care.(1, 2) Presentation can vary, and signs and symptoms of other neurodegenerative diseases overlap with those of AD. As a consequence, the accuracy of clinical diagnosis, when judged by autopsy, varies considerably.(3) Despite the recent advances in the search for relevant biomarkers to diagnose AD, such as amyloid positron emission tomography (PET) imaging agents, definitive diagnosis of AD can only be made by post-mortem histological analysis of human brain samples.(4) Post-mortem studies of AD brains have revealed two pathological hallmarks of the disease: (1) extracellular senile plaques (SPs), composed of Aβ peptides, and (2) intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs), composed of paired helical filaments (PHFs) of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.(5) Evidence for AD pathology can also be obtained from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples and brain imaging. The latter technique is noninvasive and may be used to identify patients at risk of developing AD prior to the development of indications of cognitive impairment.(6-8) Specifically, PET is a sensitive imaging technique that enables in vivo and in situ noninvasive visualization, characterization, and quantification of physiological processes at the molecular level and has become an extremely powerful diagnostic tool.(9)
    Several PET probes for in vivo imaging of Aβ-plaques have been described, of which four representative examples 1 ([11C]PiB), 2 ([18F]flutemetamol), 3a ([18F]florbetapir), and 3b ([18F]florbetaben) are shown in Chart 1.(10-14) The latter three were approved by regulatory agencies for commercial use. However, the density of amyloid plaques does not correlate well with the levels of neurodegeneration or cognitive impairment in AD.(15)
    In contrast to the amyloid pathology, the density and neocortical spread of NFTs correlate very well with progressive neuronal degeneration and cognitive decline in AD patients,(14, 16, 17) thus making PET imaging of NFTs a desirable biomarker for AD. Indeed, recently published PET imaging studies comparing amyloid PET and tau PET reported that the tau PET signal was highly correlated with cognitive performance and disease severity compared to Aβ imaging.(18-20) Whereas Aβ imaging may provide an early marker for disease risk, brain amyloid burden does not correlate with disease severity. NFT imaging may allow early detection of neurodegeneration, possibly even before the onset of cognitive symptoms, as well as predict disease progression.(21) NFT imaging may also help to delineate the relationship between the accumulation of tau aggregates and their spread as a function of time, cognition, and brain structure across the continuum from normal aging to AD. Tau aggregate imaging may also help researchers to investigate the effect of disease-modifying therapies on tau aggregation and disease progression. In addition to its involvement in AD, tau aggregation is a characteristic of other neurodegenerative diseases known as “tauopathies”,(22) which include tangle-only dementia (TD), argyrophilic grain disease (AGD), progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), corticobasal degeneration (CBD), Pick’s disease, and frontotemporal dementia and parkinsonism linked to chromosome 17 (FTDP-17). Therefore, tau aggregate imaging might be useful for the diagnosis and study of these pathologies as well, although interpretation of the in vivo signal in early PET studies of other tauopathies with current generation tau PET ligands is an active topic of debate.(23)
    The development of small molecule PET imaging radiotracers for the in vivo quantification of NFTs has been pursued by numerous academic and industrial groups.(24-28) Recently, we have reviewed these efforts as well as the multiple challenges inherent to the discovery of suitable tau PET ligands.(29) Several of these recently discovered radioligands with high binding to NFTs and selectivity over Aβ-plaques have been selected and evaluated in early clinical studies (Chart 2). The Tohoku University has described a series of 18F-labeled “THK compounds”, among which 4 ([18F]THK-5117)(30-32) and 5 ([18F]THK-5351)(33) are being extensively evaluated in the clinic. The Siemens group, now Avid/Lilly, has reported two 18F-labeled compounds 6 ([18F]AV-1451, previously known as [18F]T807),(34-38) and 7 ([18F]AV-680, previously known as [18F]T808).(25, 39) The National Institute of Radiological Sciences (NIRS) in Chiba has described a new series of 11C-labeled phenylbutadienylbenzothiazole (PBB) compounds from which 8 ([11C]PBB3)(40, 41) has also been evaluated in human subjects. Very recently Merck & Co. has reported the discovery of a new tau PET tracer 9 ([18F]MK-6240)(42) which is currently under clinical evaluation. Finally, Hoffmann-La Roche in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, reported in vitro and in vivo results with three potential tau tracers, [11C]RO6931643, [11C]RO6924963, and [18F]RO6958948,(43) but whose structures were not disclosed at the 2015 Annual Human Amyloid Imaging Conference.(43) From all these radiotracers, 6 has been the most extensively studied in AD patients. However, although 6 is very selective for tau over Aβ, recent reports suggest that it shows widespread, high affinity off-target binding; hence the signal-to-background ratio in early AD patients may not be optimal.(23, 44, 45) In addition 6 is reported to have a rather slow washout from the human brain requiring long scanning times of 80–100 min, and thus cortical (but not putamen) time–SUVR curves for 6 may not subsequently plateau within 100 min for mild cognitive impaired (MCI) or AD subjects.(46) These limitations reinforce our belief that more sensitive and selective tau PET tracers are needed. Toward this objective we started a medicinal chemistry program and herein describe our hit identification strategy and subsequent medicinal chemistry optimization that allowed the discovery of a new family of potent and selective 1,5-naphthyridines as promising tau PET tracers with potential for human use, in particular for patient selection and monitoring of disease progression in clinical trials for AD.

    Selection and Screening

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Our initial screening set was assembled from the Janssen compound collection applying two different selection strategies: (a) 2D fragment-based (ECFP6) similarity(47) via internally developed software and (b) 3D shape/pharmacophore similarity to reference compounds with known affinity for NFT using FastROCS.(48) Reference compounds 2, 4, 6, 7 and astemizole,(49) were selected from literature and scientific databases up to January 2013, the moment our search for tau PET tracers started. While being a nonselective binder to tau, we selected astemizole to increase the chemical diversity of our reference set. The FastROCS approach aligns the center of masses of the conformer shapes of the reference with conformer shapes of the database compounds.(50) Then, a sum of 3D shape similarity and 3D pharmacophore features similarity was calculated giving us a combo score. 3D pharmacophore features include HBA, HBD, anion, cation, hydrophobic and aromatic rings. FastROCS is a good tool for hit diversification, but it is sensitive to the size of the reference compounds compared to the 2D similarity methods. Thus, we have additionally applied 2D fragment-based similarity methods to get more chemically diverse compounds from internal compound database. Extended connectivity fingerprints of a size 6 (ECFP6) were used to encode the compounds and Tanimoto similarity to compare the reference compounds versus database compounds resulting in a score from 0, when no fragments are shared between compounds, to a value of 1, when shared fragments are identical between compounds.(47)
    The two ranked lists were combined using the median of individually scaled similarities; compounds with molecular weight of >700 and number of rotatable bonds between aromatic fragments of ≥3 were discarded. Additional manual filtering was applied to the combined list to reach a diverse library of ∼4000 compounds. This compound set was then screened for binding to aggregated tau extracted from human late stage AD brains (Braak V–VI)(51) using a filter binding assay with [3H]7 as a displacement probe.(52) Compounds with Ki ≤ 50 nM were subsequently screened for their selectivity versus purified amyloid β in a similar competition assay using [3H]3a as a displacement probe.(52) Following this strategy we identified N-(6-methyl-2-pyridyl)quinolin-2-amine (10, Chart 3) as an attractive starting point with good binding affinity for aggregated tau (Ki = 14 nM), moderate selectivity (∼10-fold) versus aggregated Aβ (Ki = 134 nM), and optimal physicochemical properties for achieving brain penetration (MW = 235, PSA = 38 Å2, and S + log P = 3.4 calculated with ADMET predictor).(53)
    For the medicinal chemistry optimization of 10 to potential candidate PET tracers, we defined a target product profile (TPP) with the following criteria: (i) high affinity tau binding (Ki ≤ 15 nM), (ii) over 100-fold selectivity versus Aβ binding, (iii) the presence of fluorine atom that can be easily introduced using standard radiochemistry methods, (iv) fast brain uptake and brain-to-plasma ratio of >1, and (v) fast clearance without formation of radioactive brain penetrant or defluorinated metabolites.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The synthesis routes for the preparation of compounds 10 and 30–44 are outlined in Scheme 1. While N-(pyridin-2-yl)quinolin-2-amine (11) was commercially available, compounds 10 and 30–43 were prepared via Buchwald–Hartwig aminations of (het)aryl halides (12–19) with anilines or aminopyridines (20–27), which were commercially available or obtained by straightforward and/or reported procedures (Scheme 1, route 1). The 2-naphthyl derivative 44 was prepared via the reverse Buchwald–Hartwig coupling between 2-aminonaphthalene (28) and 2-bromo-6-methylpyridine (29) (Scheme 1, route 2).
    Compounds 50–52 were synthesized as shown in Scheme 2. Thus, Buchwald–Hartwig coupling of 2-aminoquinoline (45) with (4-chloro-2-pyridinyl)methanol (46) provided alcohol 49 (Scheme 2) which was subsequently treated with DAST to provide the fluoromethyl derivative 50 with low yield. Hence for the preparation of 51–52, fluorination in the last step was avoided and both compounds were synthesized in satisfactory yields via Buchwald–Hartwig coupling of 45 with the fluorine-containing pyridyl halides 47 and 48. These in turn were conveniently prepared from commercial materials (Scheme 2).
    Compounds 58–60 were prepared via a two-step procedure (Scheme 3). First, commercially available 2-chloroquinolin-6-ol (53) or 2-chloroquinolin-7-ol (54) was O-alkylated with the corresponding fluorine-containing primary haloalkane to give fluoroalkyl ethers 55–57. Finally, reactions of the 2-chloroquinoline ethers 55–57 with 4-aminopyridine (23) under Buchwald–Hartwig conditions yielded the desired fluoroalkyloxy-substituted quinolines 58–60.
    Compound 63 was prepared from the previously reported 2-bromo-4-nitroquinoline (61) following the two-step procedure shown in Scheme 4.(54) First, Buchwald–Hartwig coupling of 61 with 23 led to the nitro substituted quinoline 62. Subsequent nucleophilic aromatic substitution of the nitro group in 62 with KF in DMSO yielded the 4-fluoroquinoline 63 in modest yield.
    The 1,7-naphthyridine derivative 68 was prepared from 4-bromo-6-fluoropyridin-3-amine (64),(55) as shown in Scheme 5. Thus, Heck coupling of 64 with methyl acrylate provided 65 in moderate yield. Next, sodium methoxide promoted intramolecular cyclization of 65 led to the bicyclic pyridine 66 with excellent yield. The 1,7-naphthyridone 66 was subsequently chlorinated with POCl3 to give 67 which was then finally coupled with 23 to provide the target molecule 68.
    1,5-Naphthyridines 74 and 75 were prepared from 2-bromo-6-fluoropyridin-3-amine (69)(56) using a similar procedure as the one outlined for 68 (Scheme 6). Thus, Heck reaction of 69 with methyl acrylate provided 70 in good yield. Cyclization of 70 under the previously described NaOMe promoted reaction conditions was unsuccessful and did not afford compound 71 but the corresponding carboxylic acid of 70. On the other hand, a literature procedure using PBu3 in AcOH proved effective in providing 71 in 93% yield.(57) Treatment of 71 with POCl3 yielded a mixture and 72 and 73 which were not separated but subsequently coupled via Buchwald–Hartwig amination with 23 or 4-amino-2-methylpyridine (24) providing 74 and 75, respectively, after isolation from the crude reaction mixture.
    In view of a potential future radiofluorination, an alternative route to 75 in which the fluorine label could be introduced in the last step was also explored (Scheme 7). Thus, 1,5-naphthyridine (76) was treated with mCPBA to provide the bis-N-oxide derivative 77. Next, rearrangement of both N-oxide functions with NMe3 in the presence of TFAA led to the bistrimethylammonium trifluoroacetate salt 78 in good yield.(58) Interestingly, one of both trimethylamine groups could be selectively substituted by treatment with the sodium salt of 24, providing after purification by RP-HPLC with 0.1% TFA buffer compound 79 as a triple TFA salt. Displacement of the remaining trimethylammonium group 79 with fluorine in DMF at 90 °C using TBAF as fluorine source provided 75 in a satisfactory 65% yield, demonstrating that intermediate 79 could be a suitable radiofluorination precursor for the preparation of [18F]75.
    Radioligand [3H]39 was prepared as follows. Monobromination of 39 occurred selectively in the 3-position of the pyridine after treatment with NBS providing 80. Next, 80 was subjected to Pd/C assisted tritio-debromination by reaction with carrier free tritium gas at rt to afford [3H]39 in high specific activity (23.6 Ci/mmol) after HPLC purification (Scheme 8).

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Prior to exploring suitable fluorination positions, a focused exploration of 10 aiming to identify key structural elements for potency and selectivity was carried out. In first instance variations around the quinoline core were explored. The quinoline nitrogen proved to be crucial for good tau binding, as the naphthalene derivative 44 showed significantly lower affinity for tau (44, Ki = 92.5 nM).(59) Variation of the nitrogen position across the quinoline core revealed an interesting and unexpected SAR: while isoquinolines 30, 33, and 34 showed potent binding to tau with Ki values lower than 35 nM, the other (iso)quinoline variations 31, 32, and 35 had much weaker affinity for tau. The quinazoline derivative 36, which can be considered a hybrid of the potent binders 10 and 30, also showed reduced affinity for tau (Table 1). Interestingly compounds 33 and 34 were the only analogues from this exploration showing increased selectivity for tau versus Aβ aggregates (205- and 33-fold, respectively) when compared to the initial hit 10.
    Table 1. Binding Results for Aggregated Tau and Aβ from the Exploration of the Quinoline Moiety in HTS Hit 10a,b
    Table a

    Ki values are a mean of at least two measurements and are given with standard deviation.

    Table b

    Selectivity ratio calculated as Ki(Aβ)/Ki(tau).

    While the similar activity of quinolones 10 and 30 can be explained by the rotational freedom around the NH bonds, which allows both molecules to present their acceptor nitrogens in similar positions, further exploration of isomers 33 and 34 suggested a distinct binding mode. This was confirmed after an extensive SAR exploration, which will be disclosed in a separate communication.
    Next, a focused exploration of the 6-methylpyridin-2-yl substituent in hit 10 was carried out (Table 2). First, the presence of the pyridine nitrogen in 10 was crucial for activity, as this was lost in the toluene analogue 37. The methyl group next to the pyridyl nitrogen in 10 was not essential for achieving good binding to aggregated tau, as the 2-pyridyl derivative 11 displayed not only improved binding but also increased selectivity versus Aβ binding (63-fold). While affinity for aggregated tau was lost in the 3-pyridyl regioisomer (38) of 11, improved potency and remarkable selectivity versus Aβ (>680-fold) were observed for the 4-pyridyl derivative 39. Both potency and selectivity were maintained in the 2-methylpyridin-4-yl derivative 40. Interestingly, binding was lost in the pyrimidine isomer 41, which displays each of the nitrogens at tolerated positions for activity in compounds 11 and 39. Finally, methylation of the NH linker in 10 significantly reduced binding affinity to aggregated tau (42, tau Ki = 2,233 nM).
    Table 2. Binding Results for Aggregated Tau and Aβ from the Exploration of the Aminopyridine Moiety in HTS Hit 10a,b
    Table a

    Ki values are a mean of at least two measurements and are given with standard deviation.

    Table b

    Selectivity ratio calculated as Ki(Aβ)/Ki(tau).

    From these initial explorations compounds 39 and 40 were the only examples that met the first two criteria of the TPP, i.e., Ki ≤ 15 nM for aggregated tau and >100-fold selectivity versus Aβ. Compound 39 is a low MW (221) compound with a PSA (38 Å2), log D (2.93) and log P (3.29) and pKa (7.51) well within the ideal boundaries for a CNS penetrant molecule.(60) On the basis of these favorable properties, 39 was further profiled and the results obtained are shown in Table 3. Metabolic stability of 39 was assessed in human (h), rat (r), and mouse liver microsomes (mLM) and was found to be low in all three species. High metabolic turnover is a desired attribute in a PET tracer, provided that the produced radiometabolites are polar and do not enter the brain, as this is likely to lead to more rapid clearance in vivo and therefore a short half-life which will help minimizing scanning time. Compound 39 was administered subcutaneously (sc) to mice at a dose of 5 mg/kg in a pharmacokinetic (PK) study to assess total brain and plasma concentrations. Compound 39 showed an excellent exposure (Cmax = 5980 ng/g) and a high total brain-to-plasma ratio (Kp) of 8.1.(61) On the basis of the AUC values in brain (5024 ng·h/g) and plasma (617 ng·h/mL) and the unbound fractions in brain (fu,b(rat) = 0.016) and plasma (fu,p(mouse) = 0.12) determined in vitro, the Kp,uu was estimated to be 1.09 in mouse. This could be expected from the low efflux ratio of 0.95 observed in an MDCK-MDR1 cell line.

    Finally, autoradiography studies were performed to assess whether the high in vitro binding of 39 translated into binding to AD brain tissue sections. To this end a tritiated analog of 39 was prepared ([3H]39, Scheme 8) and its binding profile compared to that of tritiated analogues of the selective amyloid binder [3H]3a and selective tau binder [3H]7 on human AD brain tissue sections (Braak stage V–VI as indicated by IHC with phospho-tau antibody AT8 and amyloid antibody 4G8 performed on adjacent sections). As can be seen from Figure 1, the binding pattern of [3H]39 matched that of [3H]7, thus confirming it to be a selective tau binder. By use of saturation binding experiments on adjacent sections, Kd and Bmax values were determined for [3H]7 (Kd = 5.3 nM, Bmax = 5823) and [3H]39 (Kd = 8.5 nM, Bmax = 3827); see Supporting Information.
    With the potent and selective tau ligands 39 and 40 in hand, an exploration looking for suitable positions to introduce 18F for PET imaging was initiated. The pyridine ring was first explored by modification with fluoroalkyl (50, 51) and fluoroalkyloxy chains (52). The binding results determined for aggregated tau and Aβ are shown in Table 4 and suggest that the basicity of the pyridyl nitrogen is a key factor to obtain good affinity for tau. For instance, the less basic fluoromethyl derivative 50 presented a much reduced binding to tau (50, tau Ki = 37.7 nM) compared to the methyl analogue 40 (tau Ki = 6.3 nM). The slightly more basic 2-fluoroethyl homologue 51 showed somewhat improved binding (51, tau Ki = 13.4 nM) when compared to 50 but not as good as in the case of 40. Compound 52 bearing a fluoroakyloxy chain also showed reduced affinity for tau compared to 40, confirming that the presence of a nitrogen with certain basicity is required for potent tau binding.
    Table 4. Exploration of Fluorine Tails on the Pyridine 2-Positiona,b
    compdR7tau Ki (nM)Aβ Ki (nM)selectivity (ratio)
    50CH2F37.7 ± 1.7>4400>100
    51CH2CH2F13.4 ± 2.0>4400>320
    52OCH2CH2F17.2 ± 4.5>4400>250
    a

    Ki values are a mean of at least two measurements and are given with standard deviation.

    b

    Selectivity ratio calculated as Ki(Aβ)/Ki(tau).

    Modifications around the quinoline core proved to be better tolerated for potency and offered good opportunities for the introduction of fluorine containing aliphatic chains. From recognition that the quinoline nitrogen is a key pharmacophoric element, the exploration focused on the distal 6- and 7-positions of the quinoline core (Table 5). Thus, the 6-(2-fluoroethoxy) derivative 58 maintained potency and selectivity (>750-fold) when compared to 39. In contrast, the isomeric 7-(2-fluoroethoxy) derivative 59 did not show any affinity for tau aggregates. The 6-(3-fluoropropyloxy) chain homologue 60 had similar potency and selectivity to the shorter 58. While both 58 and 60 met the first three requirements of the TPP, i.e., high affinity for tau with >100-fold selectivity over Aβ and a tolerated position to introduce a [18F], they showed high metabolic stability in hLM which, in the absence of other clearance pathways, could result in a slow clearance from plasma and subsequently slow clearance from brain. Moreover significant O-dealkylation was observed for 60 upon incubation with human liver microsomes, which risks generation of a potentially brain penetrant radiometabolite.

    Estimated from AUC0–last values, fu,b, and fu,p (m).

    In view of the challenges due to the low clearance of fluoroalkyl-substitued quinolines the introduction of aromatic fluorines on activated positions of either the pyridyl or quinoline rings was explored. Although the preparation of the 18F-labeled compounds could present some additional challenges, fluorine substituents in aromatic rings offer the advantage of being more robust against oxidative defluorination which was one of the requirements in an optimal TPP. Furthermore, a similar consideration led to the progression of 6 instead of 7, where the latter suffered from oxidative defluorination issues.(39) The introduction of a fluorine atom in the 2-position of the pyridyl ring was detrimental for affinity (43, tau Ki > 1000 nM), as could be expected due to its strong electron withdrawing effect making the pyridine nitrogen less basic. Compound 63 which carries the fluorine substituent on the quinoline 4-position showed a reduced binding affinity to tau compared to 39 (Table 6, 63, tau Ki = 18.7 nM vs Table 2, 39, tau Ki = 6.3 nM). As no other activated positions to introduce a fluorine atom were available in the quinoline core and from knowledge that the presence of nitrogen atoms in certain positions of the fused phenyl ring was tolerated for activity in compounds such as 32–35 (Table 1), a small exploration focused on fluoro-substituted naphthyridine cores was initiated. Although the data for the first representative prepared (68), bearing a 1,7-naphthyridine core, were rather disappointing (tau Ki = 263 nM), better results were obtained for the isomeric 1,5-naphthyridines 74 and 75 which maintained the good potency and high selectivity of the corresponding quinoline analogues 39 and 40.
    Table 6. Exploration of Aromatic Fluorines at Activated Positionsa,b
    Table a

    Ki values are a mean of at least two measurements and are given with standard deviation.

    Table b

    Selectivity ratio calculated as Ki(Aβ)/Ki(tau).

    Compound 75 was selected for further evaluation as a potential tau PET radiotracer. The physicochemical properties and ADME profile of 75 are compared with our internally generated data for 6 in Table 7. 1,5-Naphthyridine 75 is a low MW compound with a significantly lower experimental log P value compared to 6 (75, log P = 3.38 vs 6, log P = 4.31) and slightly higher pKa (75, pKa = 7.89 vs 6, pKa = 7.61). In line with the lower log P, 75 had higher free fraction in brain homogenate compared to 6 (75, fu,b = 0.045 vs 6, fu,b = 0.015). In addition, 75 was found to have a high unbound fraction of 0.37, 0.32, and 0.39 in mouse, rat, and human plasma, respectively. Interestingly, 75 showed consistently high microsomal clearance across species (hLM = 49.9, rLM = 98.6, and mLM = 73.3 μL min–1 mg–1) in contrast to 6, which is cleared much faster in mLM and rLM (98.6, 181 μL min–1 mg–1) compared to hLM (16.8 μL min–1 mg–1). This made 75 a good candidate for microdosing studies, as it was likely to have fast clearance/short half-life in rodent preclinical models and in human.

    The specific binding of 75 to tau was assessed by displacement studies with [3H]3a, [3H]7, and [3H]39 on human AD sections (Figure 2). The binding of selective tau binders [3H]39 and [3H]7 could be entirely displaced by treatment with 75 (Figure 2A–D). In contrast the binding of selective amyloid binders [3H]3a was not affected by treatment with 75 (Figure 2E,F). The presence and distribution of aggregated amyloid and tau in these sections were confirmed by IHC (Figure 2G,H). This suggests 75 is a highly selective binder to aggregated tau.
    The early lead 60 showed negligible clearance from cortex following iv dosing in mice in an acute microdosing study (0.03 mg/kg). Compounds 6 and 75 on the other hand showed significant clearance from brain compared to compound 60 which was in line with a previous PET tracer study with [18F]6 (Figure 3) and reflects the high in vitro CLint in mouse liver microsomes.(34) Of importance is that 75 has similar high turnover in hLM, in contrast to 6, which is significantly more stable in hLM compared to mLM and rLM (Table 7). This high metabolic stability of 6 could explain the unfavorable PK reported in human studies. Further allometric modeling confirmed a high predicted clearance for 75 in man.(65)
    On the basis of the promising clearance observed for 75 in the acute microdosing study, the compound was progressed into a more elaborate microdosing study in rat (iv, 0.03 mg/kg), in which cortex, cerebellum, and plasma levels were assessed in a 60 min time course (Figure 4). These studies were used to extract relevant PK parameters which are summarized in Table 8.
    Table 8. PK Parameters Extracted from Microdosing of 75 in Rat (0.03 mg/kg, iv)
    CL (mL min–1 kg–1)234
    plasma t1/2 (h)0.31
    plasma AUC0–1h (h·ng/mL)1.95
    cortex AUC0–1h (h·ng/g)23.9
    Vd,ss (L/kg)5.2
    Kp cortex/plasma12
    First of all, 75 showed a fast clearance from plasma of 234 mL min–1 kg–1, resulting in a short half-life of 0.31 h. In addition, 75 showed good brain exposure given the low administered dose (AUC cortex of 24.9 ng·h/mL) in line with its high Vd,ss (5.2 L/kg), and a high total cortex to plasma ratio (Kp = 12). Finally, levels in cortex and cerebellum correlated well, suggesting comparable distribution of 75 between these regions.
    A metabolic pathway study was performed for 75 in mouse, rat, dog, monkey, and human hepatocytes (Scheme 9). It was found that the same metabolites were formed in all five species, one being the result of the hydroxylation of the methyl group (81) and the other an oxidation of the 1,5-naphthyridine core (82). No defluorinated metabolites were observed across species in this assay.
    Finally, off-target binding for compound 75 was assessed via single concentration screening on a receptor panel of 52 targets (CEREP, 10 μM)(62) and 400 kinases (KINOMEscan, DiscoverX, 1 μM).(63) Of the receptor panel only the 5-HT2B receptor was found to give a significant interaction of 80% at 10 μM, which resulted in a Ki of 650 nM in concentration-response. This was not considered an issue for the developability of 75 as a PET tracer, as the 5-HT2B receptor is mostly peripherally expressed(64) and a significant 71-fold margin to aggregated tau (75, tau Ki = 7.9 nM) was achieved. Interestingly, while 75 bears a typical hydrogen bond donor (HBD)–hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) hinge-binding motif, no binding over 50% at 1 μM was observed to any of the 400 tested kinases. Finally, the inhibition of MAO-A and MAO-B, two targets known to be modestly inhibited by other tau PET tracers,(45) was assessed. Compound 75 showed no inhibition of MAO-A up to 1 mM and a IC50 of 631 μM for MAO-B.
    In conclusion, a mini-HTS of 4000 compounds selected with 3D shape/pharmacophore comparison (FastROCS) and a 2D similarity search (ECFP6) identified 10 as a potent tau aggregate binder with moderate selectivity versus aggregated Aβ. An initial SAR exploration identified key structural elements for potency and selectivity. Subsequent exploration of suitable fluorination positions identified the 1,5-naphthyridine 75. In a radioligand filter binding assay and via displacement studies on human AD sections 75 was shown to be a potent and selective tau aggregate binder. Compound 75 additionaly showed a fast clearance in two preclinical species, and in a hepatocyte study it was shown to be consistently metabolized to two major polar metabolites across species. No off-target activity was found for 75 in a receptor panel and a kinase panel, as well as no MAO-A and MAO-B inhibitory activity. On the basis of these results, compound 75 has been selected for [18F] radiolabeling and PET imaging studies in different preclinical species, the results of which will be reported in due course.(65)

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    All in vivo experimental procedures were performed according to the applicable European Communities Council Directive of November 24, 1986 (86/609/EEC) and approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee of Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson and by the local ethical committee.

    log D

    The log D was determined chromatographically at Sirius Analytical Ltd.(66)

    Nonspecific Binding to Brain Tissue and Plasma Protein Binding

    The in vitro nonspecific binding of test compounds to rat brain homogenate and the free fraction in mouse, rat, and human plasma were determined by rapid equilibrium dialysis (RED Device, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Geel, Belgium). The RED device consists of a 48-well plate containing disposable inserts bisected by a semipermeable membrane creating two chambers.

    Nonspecific Binding to Brain Tissue

    Each test compound was diluted with rat brain homogenate, prepared following a 1:10 dilution with PBS, to achieve a final concentration of 5 μM. The plate was incubated at approximately 37 °C for 5 h. After 5 h samples were removed from both the brain homogenate and buffer compartment and analyzed for test compound using a specific LCMS/MS method to estimate free and bound concentrations.

    Plasma Protein Binding

    A 300 μL aliquot of plasma containing test compound at 5 μM was placed on one side and 500 μL of phosphate buffered saline (PBS) on the other. The plate was sealed and incubated at approximately 37 °C for 4.5 h. After 4.5 h samples were removed and both the plasma and buffer compartment were analyzed for test compound using a specific LCMS/MS method to estimate free and bound concentrations.

    In Vitro Permeability/P-gp Efflux

    The in vitro permeability and potential to be transported by P-glycoprotein (P-gp) were determined using an MDCK cell line transfected with human MDR1 (P-glycoprotein). Each test compound (5 μM) was added to either the apical (A) or basolateral (B) side of a confluent monolayer of MDCK-MDR1 cells and permeability in the A → B and B → A directions measured by monitoring the appearance of the test compound on the opposite side of the membrane using a specific LCMS/MS method. Efflux ratios (B → A/A → B) were calculated to determine if the test compound was subject to efflux by P-gp.

    Metabolic Stability in Liver Microsomes (CLint)

    To test for metabolic stability, compounds (1 μM) were incubated at 37 °C with mouse, rat, and human liver microsomes at a protein concentration of 0.5 mg protein/mL microsomal protein, 1 mM NADPH, 1 mM MgCl2, and 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4. DMSO stock solutions (5 mM) of each compound were diluted with CH3CN/H2O (1:1) to provide a working stock solution at 0.1 mM. The total incubation volume was 0.5 mL with a final total solvent content of 0.01% (v/v) DMSO and 0.5% (v/v) CH3CN. The reaction was initiated by the addition of 100 μL of prewarmed NADPH solution. Sequential aliquots of the incubation mixture were removed at 0, 5, 10, 20, 40, and 60 min and quenched with 200 μL of CH3CN. Each sample was centrifuged and analyzed using a specific HPLCMS/MS technique, and the percentage of test compound remaining was used to calculate the half-life and subsequent intrinsic clearance (CLint).

    Metabolite Identification in Hepatocytes

    Compound 75 was incubated with human, rat, and mouse hepatocytes at a 1 μM compound concentration, 0.02% final DMSO concentration, and 0.24% final CH3CN concentration. The study was conducted to identify the main metabolites formed after 120 min of incubation time. The final hepatocyte density was 106 cells/mL. 40 μL incubation volume was quenched with two volumes of DMSO. Triplicates were then pooled, centrifuged for 10 min at 4000 rpm, and analyzed by UPLC/HRMS for metabolite identification (n = 1).

    PHF Tau and Aβ Isolation from Human AD Brain

    Enriched PHF tau and Aβ fractions were prepared as described by L. Declercq et al.(52) using human AD brain tissue with high tau fibril or high amyloid plaques load, respectively.

    In Vitro Competitive Radioligand Binding Assays

    The competitive radioligand binding assays measure the binding of a fixed amount of [3H]7 (tau aggregate binder) or [3H]3a (amyloid plaques binder) in the presence of a dose response concentration range of test compounds. Experimental assay setup has been described in detail by L. Declercq et al.(52)

    Immunohistochemistry

    Human brain samples were snap-frozen, sliced with a cryostat (20 μm thickness), and stored at −80 °C before use. Sections were dried, followed by formalin fixation, blocking of endogenous peroxidase with 3% hydrogen peroxide (DAKO, Glostrup, Denmark), and permeabilization in 1× PBS and 0.05% Triton X-100 during 1 h. Primary antibodies (4G8, Biolegend, San Diego, CA, USA, 2 μg/mL; AT8, in-house, 0.4 μg/mL) were diluted in antibody diluent with background reducing components (DAKO, S3022) and applied to the sections for 1 h. After extensive washing, slides were incubated with HRP-conjugated antimouse secondary antibody (Envision, DAKO), followed by chromogenic DAB labeling (DAKO). Slides were counterstained with hematoxylin, dehydrated, and mounted with organic mounting medium (Vectamount, Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA, USA). Imaging was performed with a Zeiss Axio Scan.Z1 (Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany).

    Radioligand Binding Autoradiography

    For [3H]3a slices were preincubated 15 min in 1× PBS with 1% BSA at rt. Next they were incubated for 60 min with 3 nM [3H]3a in 1× PBS with 0.1% BSA at rt. Finally slices were rinsed 3 × 10 min with 1× PBS followed by a quick dip in demineralized H2O at 4 °C. For [3H]7 and [3H]39 no preincubation was carried out. The slices were incubated for 60 min with 10 nM [3H]39 or [3H]7 in 1× PBS at rt. Next, the slices were rinsed 1 min with 1× PBS, 2 min with 70% EtOH/1× PBS, 1 min with 30% EtOH/1× PBS, and finally 1 min with 1× PBS at rt. After drying, slides were exposed to storage phosphor screens (Fujix plate) for 3 days. Autoradiograms were digitized using a Typhoon FLA-7000 imaging system (GE Healthcare Life Sciences).

    Microdosing Combined with LC/MS Detection

    Animals are kept in quarantine upon arrival for at least 4 days, with access to food and water ad libitum. Compounds were formulated with 20% HP-β-CD acidified with 0.01 N HCl until pH ≈ 3 and administered to animals intravenously (iv) at a dose of 0.03 mg/kg. Animals are sacrificed by decapitation at different time points after administration, and immediately the brain is dissected in regions of interest. The wet tissue is weighed and stored at −20 °C. The samples are homogenized in 75% CH3CN using a FastPrep homogenizer and subsequently stored at −20 °C prior to bioanalysis using UPLC/MS.

    Analytical Methods

    All final compounds were characterized by 1H NMR and HRMS.
    1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on Bruker spectrometers: 360 MHz, DPX-400 MHz, and AV-500 MHz. Purity of all final compounds was ≥95% by 1H NMR. For the 1H NMR spectra, all chemical shifts are reported in part per million (δ) units and are relative to the residual signal at 7.26 and 2.50 ppm for CDCl3 and DMSO, respectively.
    Low mass resolution LC/MS analyses were performed using a SQD (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) mass spectrometer quadrupole coupled to an Acquity or to an Acquity IClass UPLC system (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) system consisting of a binary pump with degasser, autosampler, thermostated column compartment, and diode array detector. The MS was operated with an API-ESI source. Spectra were acquired in positive and negative switching modes. The capillary voltage was set to 3.0 kV for both polarities. Nitrogen was used as the nebulizer gas. Standard LCMS methods were carried out following LCMS1, LCMS2, LCMS3, and LCMS4 conditions shown below, as described for each compound. The standard injection volume was 2 μL. Data acquisition was performed with MassLynx/OpenLynx 4.1 software (Waters, Milford, MA, USA). High mass resolution analyses were performed using a Xevo G2-S QTOF MS (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) coupled to an IClass UPLC (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) system consisting of a binary pump with degasser, autosampler, thermostated column compartment, and diode array detector. The MS was operated with an API-ESI source. Spectra were acquired in positive mode. The capillary voltage was set to 0.25 kV. The cone voltage was set to 25 V. The source temperature was maintained at 140 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 50–1200. Nitrogen was used as the nebulizer gas and argon as collision gas. Standard reversed phase gradients were carried out following LCMS4 conditions detailed below. The standard injection volume was 2 μL. A Lockmass device with leucine-enkephalin as standard substance was used for mass calibration. Data acquisition was performed with MassLynx/OpenLynx 4.1 software (Waters, Milford, MA, USA). Radiochemistry low mass resolution LC/MS analyses for [3H]39 were performed using a mass spectrometer quadrupole coupled to a 1200 HPLC system (Agilent Santa Clara, CA, USA) consisting of a quaternary pump with degasser, autosampler, thermostated column compartment, and diode array detector. The MS was operated with an API-ESI source. Spectra were acquired in positive mode. The capillary voltage was set to 1 kV, and the fragmentor voltage was 70 V. The source temperature was maintained at 100 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 90–1500. Nitrogen was used as the nebulizer gas. Standard reversed phase gradients were carried out following LCMS5 conditions detailed below. The standard injection volume was 2 μL. Data acquisition was performed with Chemstation software (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA).

    LCMS1 Conditions

    LC: Reversed phase UPLC was carried out on a HSS T3 column (1.8 μm, 2.1 mm × 100 mm) from Waters, with a flow rate of 0.7 mL/min, at 55 °C. The gradient conditions used are 100% A (NH4OAc, 10 mM in H2O + 5% CH3CN), 0% B (CH3CN), to 95% A in 2.1 min, to 0% A in 0.9 min, held for 0.5 min. Acquisition range for the UV-PDA detector was set to 210–400 nm. MS: Cone voltage was 30 V for both polarities. The source temperature was maintained at 150 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 120–1000.
    LCMS2 Conditions. LC: Reversed phase UPLC was carried out on a BEH C18 column (1.7 μm, 2.1 mm × 50 mm) from Waters, with a flow rate of 0.8 mL/min, at 55 °C. The gradient conditions used are 95% A (NH4OAc, 10 mM in H2O + 5% CH3CN), 5% B (CH3CN), to 5% A in 1.3 min, held for 0.7 min. Acquisition range for the UV-PDA detector was set to 210–400 nm. MS: Cone voltage was 30 V for both polarities. The source temperature was maintained at 150 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 120–1000.
    LCMS3 Conditions. LC: Reversed phase UPLC was carried out on a CSH C18 column (1.7 μm, 2.1 mm × 50 mm) from Waters, with a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min, at 50 °C. The gradient conditions used are 95% A (NH4OAc, 6.5 mM in H2O + 5% CH3CN), 5% B (CH3CN), to 40% A in 1.2 min, to 5% A in 0.6 min, held for 0.2 min. Acquisition range for the UV-PDA detector was set to 200–450 nm. MS (SQD): Cone voltage was 25 V for positive and 30 V for negative modes. The source temperature was maintained at 140 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 100–1000.
    LCMS4 Conditions. Reversed phase UPLC was carried out on a BEH C18 column (1.7 μm, 2.1 mm × 50 mm) from Waters, with a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min, at 50 °C. The gradient conditions used are 95% A (NH4OAc, 6.5 mM in H2O + 5% CH3CN), 5% B (CH3CN), to 40% A in 1.2 min, to 5% A in 0.6 min, held for 0.2 min. Acquisition range for the UV-PDA detector was set to 200–450 nm. MS: (SQD) Cone voltage was 25 V for positive and 30 V for negative modes. The source temperature was maintained at 140 °C. Acquisition mass range was m/z 100–1000. MS (QTOF): see general description.
    LCMS5 Conditions. LC: reversed phase HPLC was carried out on an Agilent Zorbax SB-C18 column (3.5 μm, 2.1 mm × 30 mm) from Agilent, with a flow rate of 0.75 mL/min at 35 °C. The gradient conditions used are 90% A (H2O, + 0.1% TFA), 10% B (CH3CN + 0.1% TFA), to 0% A in 4 min, held for 2 min and equilibrated to initial conditions in 0.1 min, held for 1.9 min. Acquisition for the UV-DAD detector was set to 210, 254, and 280 nm. MS (6140 quadrupole): see general description.
    For 79 H2O (% w/w) was determined with a CA-02-moisture meter (Mitsubishi) by coulometric principle applied to Karl Fischer titration.
    For 79, amount of carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen (CHN) in (% w/w) was determined by dynamic flash combustion on an EA 1108 CHN analyzer from Fisons instruments.
    For 79, anions were detected with a DX-120 instrument from Dionex. An Ion Pac AS14 was used with eluent (3.5 mM Na2CO3/1 mM NaHCO3 in H2O).

    Synthetic Protocols

    The following compounds were obtained commercially or prepared using reported procedures: N-(pyridin-2-yl)quinolin-2-amine (11, Chembridge),(67) 2-chloroquinoline (12), 3-chloroisoquinoline (13), 3-bromoquinoline (14), 6-iodoquinoline (15), 6-bromoisoquinoline (16), 7-bromoisoquinoline (17), 7-bromoquinoline (18), 2-chloroquinazoline (19), 6-methylpyridin-2-amine (20), 3-methylaniline (21), 3-aminopyridine (22), 4-aminopyridine (23), 2-methylpyridin-4-amine (24), pyrimidin-4-amine (25), N,6-dimethylpyridin-2-amine (26),(68) 2-fluoropyridin-4-amine (27), naphthalen-2-amine (28), 2-bromo-6-methylpyridine (29), 2-aminoquinoline (45), (4-chloro-2-pyridinyl)methanol (46), 2-chloroquinolin-6-ol (53), 2-chloroquinolin-7-ol (54), 2-bromo-4-nitroquinoline (61),(69) 4-bromo-6-fluoropyridin-3-amine 64, 2-bromo-6-fluoro-3-pyridinamine 69.(70)

    N-(6-Methylpyridin-2-yl)quinolin-2-amine (10)

    This compound was obtained commercially(71) but was resynthesized because no analytical data were reported in literature: To a solution of 2-chloroquinoline 12 (300 mg, 1.83 mmol) in tert-butanol (7.2 mL) were added 6-methylpyridin-2-amine 20 (220 mg, 2.04 mmol), Pd(OAc)2 (8.2 mg, 0.037 mmol), XantPhos (21 mg, 0.037 mmol), and Cs2CO3 (1.67 g, 5.13 mmol). The mixture was flushed with nitrogen and heated at 90 °C for 10 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. Next, the mixture was concentrated under reduced pressure, taken up in H2O, extracted with DCM, dried on MgSO4, filtered, and evaporated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography with silica gel (gradient DCM/MeOH from 100/0 to 95/5). The product fractions were evaporated providing 10 as off-white crystals (211 mg, 49%).     A mixture of 66 (280 mg, 1.706 mmol) in POCl3 (10 mL, 107.61 mmol) was heated at 120 °C for 20 min under microwave irradiation. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and then poured into ice while stirring. NaHCO3 aq sat. solution was added until pH 7–8. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc and the combined organic layers washed were dried (MgSO4), filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. A yellow solid was obtained which was used as such for the next reaction step (67, 383 mg). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 1.60, 79.76% pure, no ionization achieved.

    6-Fluoro-N-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,7-naphthyridin-2-amine (68)

    The compound was prepared using the same procedure as 49 starting from 67 (150 mg, 0.78 mmol) and 4-aminopyridine 23 (81 mg 0.859 mmol) yielding 68 as a white fluffy solid (56 mg, 30%, 2 steps). Mp: 276.5 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.15 (s, 1H), 8.87 (s, 1H), 8.40–8.47 (m, 2H), 8.25 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H), 7.95–7.99 (m, 2H), 7.55 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.39 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H). HRMS calcd for C13H10FN4 [M + H]+ 241.0884, found 241.0893.

    Methyl (2E)-3-(3-Amino-6-fluoropyridin-2-yl)prop-2-enoate (70)

    A mixture of 2-bromo-6-fluoro-3-pyridinamine 69 (20 g, 96.33 mmol), methyl acrylate (13.01 mL, 144.50 mmol), Pd(OAc)2 (2.81 g, 12.52 mmol), PPh3 (5.81 g, 22.16 mmol), and TEA (30.13 mL, 216.75 mmol) in THF (143 mL) was heated in a sealed tube at 140 °C for 2 h. The reaction was cooled to rt. NaHCO3 (sat. solution) and EtOAc were 30 added, and the phases were separated. The aqueous phase was extracted twice more with EtOAc. The combined organic layers were dried over MgSO4, filtered, and evaporated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography (silica; dry loading; heptane/EtOAc 100/0 to 60/40). The desired fractions were collected, and the solvents were evaporated to yield 70 (17.6 g, 93%) as an orange solid. 1H NMR (360 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 10.10 (s, 1 H), 8.36–8.45 (m, 3 H), 8.12 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.94 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2 H), 7.49 (dd, J = 9.0, 2.7 Hz, 1 H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1 H). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 1.43, 97.21% pure, m/z 197 [M + H]+.

    6-Fluoro-1,5-naphthyridin-2(1H)-one (71)

    A mixture of 70 (14.8 g, 75.44 mmol) and tri-n-butylphosphine (18.84 mL, 75.44 mmol) in AcOH (107.87 mL) was heated in a sealed tube at 110 °C for 1 h. The mixture was evaporated and then stirred in DIPE (500 mL). The solids were filtered off and dried under vacuum at 50 °C overnight, yielding intermediate 71 (11.3 g, 91%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (360 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 12.05 (br s, 1H), 7.85 (dd, J = 6.9, 8.8 Hz, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 1H), 7.36 (dd, J = 2.9, 8.8 Hz, 1H), 6.79 (d, J = 9.9 Hz, 1H). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 0.98, 88.74% pure, m/z 165 [M + H]+.

    2-Chloro-6-fluoro-1,5-naphthyridine (72) and 2,6-Dichloro-1,5-naphthyridine (73)

    POCl3 (1.925 mL, 20.71 mmol) was added to a suspension of 73 (5 g, 20.71 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (64.32 mL), and the mixture was heated in a pressure tube at 110 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was evaporated, taken up in a sat. aq. NaHCO3, extracted with DCM, dried over MgSO4, and evaporated. The residue was purified by column chromatography (silica gel; heptane/EtOAc 100/0 to 80/20 (dry loading)). The desired fractions were evaporated, yielding 72 (3.36 g) as a white solid (the sample was determined to contain 13 mol % 73). 1H NMR (360 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 8.36–8.45 (m, 1 H), 8.21 (dd, J = 8.8, 0.7 Hz, 1 H), 7.65 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.35 (dd, J = 9.1, 2.9 Hz, 1 H). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 1.66, 79.18% pure, m/z 183 [M + H]+.

    6-Fluoro-N-(pyridin-4-yl)-1,5-naphthyridin-2-amine (74)

    The compound was prepared using the same procedure as 10 starting from 72 (200 mg, 1.10 mmol) and 4-aminopyridine (114.43 mg, 1.22 mmol) yielding 74, as a yellow solid after trituration with DIPE/H2O, filtering, and drying in vacuo (46 mg, 17%, 2 steps). Mp: amorphous. 1H NMR (360 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 10.10 (s, 1 H), 8.36–8.45 (m, 3 H), 8.12 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.94 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2 H), 7.49 (dd, J = 9.0, 2.7 Hz, 1 H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1 H). HRMS calcd for C13H10FN4 [M + H]+ 241.0884, found 241.0895.

    6-Fluoro-N-(2-methylpyridin-4-yl)-1,5-naphthyridin-2-amine (75)

    Procedure a

    The compound was prepared using the same procedure as 10 starting from 72 (1.66 g, 15.34 mmol) and 2-methyl-4-pyridinamine 24 (1.66 g, 15.34 mmol) yielding 75 as a yellow solid after purification via preparative HPLC (stationary phase, RP XBridge Prep C18 OBD, 10 μm, 50 mm × 150 mm; mobile phase, 0.25% NH4HCO3 solution in H2O, MeOH) (915 mg, 24%, 2 steps). Mp: 248.0 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 9.97 (s, 1 H), 8.39 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 1 H), 8.28 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1 H), 8.10 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1 H), 7.72–7.85 (m, 2 H), 7.48 (dd, J = 8.9, 2.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.39 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 1 H), 2.45 (s, 3 H). HRMS calcd for C14H12FN4 [M + H]+ 255.1041, found 255.1047.

    Procedure b

    TBAF (1 M in THF, 0.28 mL, 0.28 mmol) was added to a solution of 79 (38 mg, 0.093 mmol) in DMF (0.93 mL). The resulting mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 30 min. All volatiles were evaporated. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography over silica gel using a gradient (DCM/7 N NH3 in MeOH, 1:0 to 9:1). The product fractions were evaporated providing 75 (15.4 mg, 65%) as yellow crystals.

    1,5-Naphthyridine 1,5-Dioxide (77)

    3-Chlorobenzoperoxoic acid (164.4 g, 666.9 mmol) was added to a solution of 1,5-naphthyridine 76 (28.0 g, 215.1 mmol) in DCM (1.4 L) and MeOH (0.7 L). The reaction mixture was stirred at rt for 3 h. More 3-chlorobenzoperoxoic acid (53.0 g, 215.1 mmol) was added, and stirring was continued for 72 h. A solid was formed which was filtered. The filtrate was half concentrated, and more precipitate formed which was filtered and combined with the precipitate obtained before. This solid was triturated with DCM/MeOH (9:1), filtered, and dried in vacuo yielding 77 (28.0 g, 172.7 mmol, 80%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (360 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.73 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2H), 8.29 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 2H), 7.70 (dd, J = 6.0, 9.0 Hz, 2H). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 0.61, 99.09% pure, m/z 163 [M + H]+.

    N,N,N,N′,N′,N′-Hexamethyl-1,5-naphthyridine-2,6-diaminium Bis(trifluoroacetate) (78)

    Trifluoroacetic anhydride (69.5 mL, 499.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 77 (27.0 g, 166.5 mmol) and trimethylamine (1 M in THF, 0.85 L, 850 mmol) in DCM (1.35 L) at 0 °C. The mixture was stirred at rt. Upon completion (about 30 min), Et2O (1 L) was added and stirring was continued for 1 h. The white salts were isolated by filtration, washed with Et2O, and dried in vacuo overnight to yield 78 (68 g, 144.0 mmol, 86%). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 0.41, m/z 123 [M]2+.

    2-Methyl-4-{[6-(trimethylammonio)-1,5-naphthyridin-2-yl]ammonio}pyridinium Tris(trifluoroacetate) Monohydrate (79)

    NaH (60% dispersion in mineral oil, 4.92 g, 122.98 mmol) was added to a mixture of intermediate 78 (9.68 g, 20.50 mmol) and 4-amino-2-methylpyridine 24 (2.22 g, 20.50 mmol) in DMF (dry on molecular sieves, 202.3 mL) at 0 °C. The resulting mixture was stirred for 20 min (red color developed) while slowly warming to rt. The solvent was evaporated to dryness, the residue was dissolved in EtOAc, then H2O was added and the mixture was evaporated yielding crude 79 as a yellow solid that was purified via prep HPLC (stationary phase, Uptisphere C18 ODB, 10 μm, 200 g, 5 cm; mobile phase, 0.1% TFA solution in H2O + 5% CH3CN, MeOH) to provide a solid that was taken up in Et2O, filtered, and then dried in vacuo at 40 °C overnight 79 (triple TFA salt and monohydrate, 2.4 g, 29%) as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 11.56 (s, 1 H), 8.81 (dd, J = 9.2, 0.7 Hz, 1 H), 8.55 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 1 H), 8.45–8.52 (m, 3 H), 8.19 (br d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.71 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 1 H), 3.71 (s, 9 H), 2.71 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 161.13 (s, 1 C), 158.15 (s, 1 C), 155.52 (s, 1 C), 154.79 (s, 1 C), 153.17 (s, 1 C), 150.39 (s, 1 C), 144.98 (s, 1 C), 142.01 (s, 1 C), 139.64 (s, 1 C), 138.24 (s, 1 C), 137.62 (s, 1 C), 135.80 (s, 1 C), 120.28 (s, 1 C), 116.31 (s, 1 C), 112.30 (s, 1 C), 111.06 (s, 1 C), 69.84 (s, 1 C), 54.68 (s, 1 C), 38.30 (s, 1 C), 21.81 (s, 1 C). In addition a quartet at δ ppm 157.99 (J = 33 Hz) and 117.44 (J = 301 Hz) confirmed the presence of trifluoroacetate. H2O content (coulometry): 0.8 mol. TFA content (IC): 3 mol. LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 1.00, 100.00% pure, m/z 294 [M]+.
    Note: The double TFA salt and hemihydrate could be obtained as follows. The salt obtained from HPLC purification was triturated overnight in a large volume of Et2O, and the resulting fine yellow powder was filtered and washed with ether, dried overnight in vacuo at 55 °C and then for 24 h in a lyophilizer at room temperature. 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6, 61 °C) δ ppm 11.68 (br s, 1 H), 8.69 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 1 H), 8.52 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 1 H), 8.45 (d, J = 9.2 Hz, 1 H), 8.40 (s,1 H), 8.36 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1 H), 8.30 (br d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1 H), 7.82 (d, J = 9.1 Hz, 1 H), 3.71 (s, 9 H), 2.65 (s, 3 H). H2O content (coulometry): 0.4 mol. TFA content (IC): 2 mol TFA. Anal. Calcd for C17H20N5·C2F3O2·C2HF3O2·0.4H2O: C, 47.71; H, 4.16; N, 13.25. Found: C, 47.18; H, 4.04; N, 13.13. LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 0.99, 96.14% pure, m/z 294 [M]+.

    N-[(3-3H)Pyridin-4-yl]quinolin-2-amine ([3H]39)

    Synthesis of the Precursor N-(3-Bromopyridin-4-yl)quinolin-2-amine (80)

    NBS (150 mg, 0.843 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 39 (170 mg, 0.768 mmol) in 4 mL of CHCl3 and a few drops of MeOH at rt, and the resulting mixture was heated to 60 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was evaporated and the residue purified by flash chromatography (silica; EtOAc in DCM, 0/100 to 10/90). The desired fractions were collected and solvents removed in vacuo to afford 80 as a white solid (59 mg, 26%). 1H NMR (360 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 8.72–8.91 (m, 2 H), 8.64 (s, 1 H), 8.41 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 1 H), 8.25 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.75–7.88 (m, 2 H), 7.67 (ddd, J = 8.4, 6.9, 1.5 Hz, 1 H), 7.56 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1 H), 7.43 (ddd, J = 8.0, 6.9, 1.3 Hz, 1 H). LCMS (LCMS1 conditions) tR = 1.15, 100% pure, m/z 300 [M + H]+.

    Synthesis of N-[(3-3H)Pyridin-4-yl]quinolin-2-amine ([3H]39)

    A reaction vessel was charged with 3 mg of the bromide precursor 80, 5 mg of 10% Pd/C, and 0.3 mL of DMF containing 3 μL of DIPEA. The mixture was cooled in liquid nitrogen, the system was subjected to 3 cycles of degassing in vacuo, then treated with 10 Ci tritium gas with the pressure 760 mmHg. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 3 h. The crude product was purified on a HPLC Capcell Pak C-18 column using the following instrument parameters. The flow rate was 6.0 mL/min, UV 275 nm, with mobile phase A of 0.1% TFA in H2O and mobile phase B of 0.1% TFA in acetonitrile. Elution was completed using an isocratic of 30% B. Retention time was at 30 min. 10 mCi [3H]39 was isolated in 99.4% radiochemical purity with specific activity of 23.6 Ci/mmol. 3H NMR (320 MHz, MeOD) δ ppm 8.55 (s, 1 H). LCMS tR = 12.45 min, 99.4% radiochemical purity, m/z [M + H]+ 224.43.

      2
      Alzheimer's disease: strategies for disease modification
      Citron, Martin
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2010), 9 (5), 387-398CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Alzheimer's disease is the largest unmet medical need in neurol. Current drugs improve symptoms, but do not have profound disease-modifying effects. However, in recent years, several approaches aimed at inhibiting disease progression have advanced to clin. trials. Among these, strategies targeting the prodn. and clearance of the amyloid-β peptide - a cardinal feature of Alzheimer's disease that is thought to be important in disease pathogenesis - are the most advanced. Approaches aimed at modulating the abnormal aggregation of tau filaments (another key feature of the disease), and those targeting metabolic dysfunction, are also being evaluated in the clinic. This article discusses recent progress with each of these strategies, with a focus on anti-amyloid strategies, highlighting the lessons learned and the challenges that remain.

P.; Haroutunian, V.; Hof, P. R.; Hulette, C. M.; Hyman, B. T.; Iwatsubo, T.; Jellinger, K. A.; Jicha, G. A.; Kovari, E.; Kukull, W. A.; Leverenz, J. B.; Love, S.; Mackenzie, I. R.; Mann, D. Correlation of Alzheimer disease neuropathologic changes with cognitive status: a review of the literature J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 2012, 71, 362– 381 DOI: 10.1097/NEN.0b013e31825018f7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Correlation of Alzheimer disease neuropathologic changes with cognitive status: a review of the literature
      Nelson Peter T; Alafuzoff Irina; Bigio Eileen H; Bouras Constantin; Braak Heiko; Cairns Nigel J; Castellani Rudolph J; Crain Barbara J; Davies Peter; Del Tredici Kelly; Duyckaerts Charles; Frosch Matthew P; Haroutunian Vahram; Hof Patrick R; Hulette Christine M; Hyman Bradley T; Iwatsubo Takeshi; Jellinger Kurt A; Jicha Gregory A; Kovari Eniko; Kukull Walter A; Leverenz James B; Love Seth; Mackenzie Ian R; Mann David M; Masliah Eliezer; McKee Ann C; Montine Thomas J; Morris John C; Schneider Julie A; Sonnen Joshua A; Thal Dietmar R; Trojanowski John Q; Troncoso Juan C; Wisniewski Thomas; Woltjer Randall L; Beach Thomas G
      Journal of neuropathology and experimental neurology (2012), 71 (5), 362-81 ISSN:.
      Clinicopathologic correlation studies are critically important for the field of Alzheimer disease (AD) research. Studies on human subjects with autopsy confirmation entail numerous potential biases that affect both their general applicability and the validity of the correlations. Many sources of data variability can weaken the apparent correlation between cognitive status and AD neuropathologic changes. Indeed, most persons in advanced old age have significant non-AD brain lesions that may alter cognition independently of AD. Worldwide research efforts have evaluated thousands of human subjects to assess the causes of cognitive impairment in the elderly, and these studies have been interpreted in different ways. We review the literature focusing on the correlation of AD neuropathologic changes (i.e. β-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles) with cognitive impairment. We discuss the various patterns of brain changes that have been observed in elderly individuals to provide a perspective for understanding AD clinicopathologic correlation and conclude that evidence from many independent research centers strongly supports the existence of a specific disease, as defined by the presence of Aβ plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Although Aβ plaques may play a key role in AD pathogenesis, the severity of cognitive impairment correlates best with the burden of neocortical neurofibrillary tangles.

      4
      Diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
      Delacourte A
      Annales de biologie clinique (1998), 56 (2), 133-42 ISSN:0003-3898.
      Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder leading to cognitive impairment (amnesia, aphasia, apraxia and agnosia). The prevalence of this age related disabling illness is increasing. During the course of the disease, the clinical diagnosis will be that of "possible Alzheimer's disease", then "probable Alzheimer's disease". But the diagnosis of "definite Alzheimer's disease" requires a post-mortem brain examination and the demonstration of numerous senile plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in hippocampal and association cortical areas. The neuropathological examination confirms probable Alzheimer's disease clinical diagnosis in 85% of the cases examined in medical schools. However, with much more than 15% errors, the early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease must be improved since it is a key factor for the therapeutic approach, and more especially for the efficiency of drug trials. At the present time, there are new leads for a biological diagnosis in the blood or the CSF. However, the natural (and molecular) history of Alzheimer's disease points out that all biochemical dysfunctions remain in the CNS, and more particularly in association brain areas. This is demonstrated using reliable biochemical markers such as A beta and pathological Tau proteins, which are the basic components of amyloid deposits and neurofibrillary tangles, respectively. Also, a genetic diagnosis can be performed in half of familial autosomic dominant Alzheimer's disease, which represents less than 1% of all Alzheimer's disease cases. Together, this shows that there is a lack of reliable Alzheimer's disease markers. The search for new specific markers (clinical, epidemiological, genetic, biochemical, biological) must go on.

They include the use of Thioflavin-T for the monitoring of Aβ aggregation, the investigations of new PET and SPECT imaging agents for the detection of the senile plaques, the development of bi-functional mols., encompassing the 2-arylbenzazole moiety for Aβ binding and a chelating unit for metal ions coordination for instance.

      The challenges of tau imaging

      A review. Many hypotheses have been raised regarding the pathophysiol. of Alzheimer's disease (AD).       Neurofibrillary tangles but not senile plaques parallel duration and severity of Alzheimer's disease
      Arriagada P V; Growdon J H; Hedley-Whyte E T; Hyman B T
      Neurology (1992), 42 (3 Pt 1), 631-9 ISSN:0028-3878.
      We studied the accumulation of neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and senile plaques (SPs) in 10 Alzheimer's disease patients who had been examined during life. We counted NFTs and SPs in 13 cytoarchitectural regions representing limbic, primary sensory, and association cortices, and in subcortical neurotransmitter-specific areas. The degree of neuropathologic change was compared with the severity of dementia, as assessed by the Blessed Dementia Scale and duration of illness. We found that (1) the severity of dementia was positively related to the number of NFTs in neocortex, but not to the degree of SP deposition; (2) NFTs accumulate in a consistent pattern reflecting hierarchic vulnerability of individual cytoarchitectural fields; (3) NFTs appeared in the entorhinal cortex, CA1/subiculum field of the hippocampal formation, and the amygdala early in the disease process; and (4) the degree of SP deposition was also related to a hierarchic vulnerability of certain brain areas to accumulate SPs, but the pattern of SP distribution was different from that of NFT.

      OBJECTIVE: Detection of focal brain tau deposition during life could greatly facilitate accurate diagnosis of Alzheimer disease (AD), staging and monitoring of disease progression, and development of disease-modifying therapies. METHODS: We acquired tau positron emission tomography (PET) using (18)F T807 (AV1451), and amyloid-β PET using (11)C Pittsburgh compound B (PiB) in older clinically normal individuals, and symptomatic patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild AD dementia. INTERPRETATION: These findings suggest that (18)F T807 PET could have value as a biomarker that reflects both the progression of AD tauopathy and the emergence of clinical impairment.

      In vivo cortical spreading pattern of tau and amyloid in the Alzheimer disease spectrum
      Cho, Hanna; Choi, Jae Yong; Hwang, Mi Song; Kim, You Jin; Lee, Hye Mi; Lee, Hye Sun; Lee, Jae Hoon; Ryu, Young Hoon; Lee, Myung Sik; Lyoo, Chul Hyoung
      Annals of Neurology (2016), 80 (2), 247-258CODEN: ANNED3; ISSN:0364-5134. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      Objective : To det. the in vivo cortical spreading pattern of tau and amyloid and to establish positron emission tomog. (PET) image-based tau staging in the Alzheimer disease (AD) spectrum. Methods : We included 195 participants (53 AD, 52 amnestic mild cognitive impairment [MCI], 23 nonamnestic MCI, and 67 healthy controls) who underwent 2 PET scans (18F-florbetaben for amyloid-β and 18F-AV-1451 for tau). We assumed that regions with earlier appearances of pathol. may show increased binding in a greater no. of participants and acquired spreading order of tau accumulation by sorting the regional frequencies of involvement. We classified each participant into image-based tau stage based on the Z score of the composite region for each stage. Results : Tau accumulation was most frequently obsd. in the medial temporal regions and spread stepwise to the basal and lateral temporal, inferior parietal, posterior cingulate, and other assocn. cortices, and then ultimately to the primary cortical regions. In contrast, amyloid accumulation was found with similar frequency in the diffuse neocortical areas and then finally spread to the medial temporal regions. The image-based tau stage correlated with the general cognitive status, whereas cortical thinning was found only in the advanced tau stages: medial temporal region in stage V and widespread cortex in stage VI. Interpretation : Our PET study replicated postmortem spreading patterns of tau and amyloid-β pathologies. Unlike the diffuse accumulation of amyloid throughout the neocortex, tau spreading occurred in a stepwise fashion through the networks. Image-based tau staging may be useful for the objective assessment of AD progression.

      Tau pathology and neurodegeneration
      Spillantini, Maria Grazia; Goedert, Michel
      Lancet Neurology (2013), 12 (6), 609-622CODEN: LNAEAM; ISSN:1474-4422. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. The pathway leading from sol. and monomeric to hyperphosphorylated, insol. and filamentous tau protein is at the center of many human neurodegenerative diseases, collectively referred to as tauopathies. Dominantly inherited mutations in MAPT, the gene that encodes tau, cause forms of frontotemporal dementia and parkinsonism, proving that dysfunction of tau is sufficient to cause neurodegeneration and dementia. However, most cases of tauopathy are not inherited in a dominant manner. The first tau aggregates form in a few nerve cells in discrete brain areas. These become self propagating and spread to distant brain regions in a prion-like manner. The prevention of tau aggregation and propagation is the focus of attempts to develop mechanism-based treatments for tauopathies.

      An autoradiographic evaluation of AV-1451 Tau PET in dementia
      Lowe Val J; Curran Geoffry; Fang Ping; Kantarci Kejal; Pandey Mukesh K; Bruinsma Tyler; Jack Clifford R Jr; Liesinger Amanda M; Petrucelli Leonard; Cook Casey N; Dickson Dennis W; Murray Melissa E; Josephs Keith A; Parisi Joseph E; Boeve Bradley F; Knopman David S; Jones David T; Petersen Ronald C; Parisi Joseph E; Graff-Radford Neill R
      Acta neuropathologica communications (2016), 4 (1), 58 ISSN:.
      BACKGROUND: It is essential to determine the specificity of AV-1451 PET for tau in brain imaging by using pathological comparisons. We performed autoradiography in autopsy-confirmed Alzheimer disease and other neurodegenerative disorders to evaluate the specificity of AV-1451 binding for tau aggregates. METHODS: Tissue samples were selected that had a variety of dementia-related neuropathologies including Alzheimer disease, primary age-related tauopathy, tangle predominant dementia, non-Alzheimer disease tauopathies, frontotemporal dementia, parkinsonism, Lewy body disease and multiple system atrophy (n = 38). Brain tissue sections were stained for tau, TAR DNA-binding protein-43, and α-synuclein and compared to AV-1451 autoradiography on adjacent sections. RESULTS: AV-1451 preferentially localized to neurofibrillary tangles, with less binding to areas enriched in neuritic pathology and less mature tau. The strength of AV-1451 binding with respect to tau isoforms in various neurodegenerative disorders was: 3R + 4R tau (e.g., AD) > 3R tau (e.g., Pick disease) or 4R tau. Only minimal binding of AV-1451 to TAR DNA-binding protein-43 positive regions was detected. No binding of AV-1451 to α-synuclein was detected. "Off-target" binding was seen in vessels, iron-associated regions, substantia nigra, calcifications in the choroid plexus, and leptomeningeal melanin. CONCLUSIONS: Reduced AV-1451 binding in neuritic pathology compared to neurofibrillary tangles suggests that the maturity of tau pathology may affect AV-1451 binding and suggests complexity in AV-1451 binding. Poor association of AV-1451 with tauopathies that have preferential accumulation of either 4R tau or 3R tau suggests limited clinical utility in detecting these pathologies. In contrast, for disorders associated with 3R + 4R tau, such as Alzheimer disease, AV-1451 binds tau avidly but does not completely reflect the early stage tau progression suggested by Braak neurofibrillary tangle staging. AV-1451 binding to TAR DNA-binding protein-43 or TAR DNA-binding protein-43 positive regions can be weakly positive. Clinical use of AV-1451 will require a familiarity with distinct types of "off-target" binding.

      Tau imaging: early progress and future directions
      Villemagne Victor L; Fodero-Tavoletti Michelle T; Masters Colin L; Rowe Christopher C
      The Lancet. Neurology (2015), 14 (1), 114-24 ISSN:.
      Use of selective in-vivo tau imaging will enable improved understanding of tau aggregation in the brain, facilitating research into causes, diagnosis, and treatment of major tauopathies such as Alzheimer's disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal syndrome, chronic traumatic encephalopathy, and some variants of frontotemporal lobar degeneration. Neuropathological studies of Alzheimer's disease show a strong association between tau deposits, decreased cognitive function, and neurodegenerative changes. Selective tau imaging will allow the in-vivo exploration of such associations and measure the global and regional changes in tau deposits over time. Such imaging studies will comprise non-invasive assessment of the spatial and temporal pattern of tau deposition over time, providing insight into the role tau plays in ageing and helping to establish the relation between cognition, genotype, neurodegeneration, and other biomarkers. Once validated, selective tau imaging might be useful as a diagnostic, prognostic, and progression biomarker, and a surrogate marker for the monitoring of efficacy and patient recruitment for anti-tau therapeutic trials.

      Tau PET imaging in Alzheimer's disease
      Okamura Nobuyuki; Harada Ryuichi; Furumoto Shozo; Arai Hiroyuki; Yanai Kazuhiko; Kudo Yukitsuka
      Current neurology and neuroscience reports (2014), 14 (11), 500 ISSN:.
      In several neurodegenerative diseases that are collectively called tauopathies, progressive accumulation of tau in the brain is closely associated with neurodegeneration and cognitive impairment. Noninvasive detection of tau protein deposits in the brain would be useful to diagnose tauopathies as well as to track and predict disease progression. Recently, several tau PET tracers including T807, THK-5117, and PBB3 have been developed and succeeded in imaging neurofibrillary pathology in vivo. For use of tau PET as a biomarker of tau pathology in Alzheimer's disease, PET tracers should have high affinity to PHF-tau and high selectivity for tau over amyloid-β and other protein deposits. PET tau imaging enables the longitudinal assessment of the spatial pattern of tau deposition and its relation to amyloid-β pathology and neurodegeneration. This technology could also be applied to the pharmacological assessment of anti-tau therapy, thereby allowing preventive interventions.

      Novel 18F-labeled arylquinoline derivatives for noninvasive imaging of tau pathology in Alzheimer disease
      Okamura, Nobuyuki; Furumoto, Shozo; Harada, Ryuichi; Tago, Tetsuro; Yoshikawa, Takeo; Fodero-Tavoletti, Michelle; Mulligan, Rachel S.; Villemagne, Victor L.; Akatsu, Hiroyasu; Yamamoto, Takayuki; Arai, Hiroyuki; Iwata, Ren; Yanai, Kazuhiko; Kudo, Yukitsuka
      Journal of Nuclear Medicine (2013), 54 (8), 1420-1427CODEN: JNMEAQ; ISSN:0161-5505. (Society of Nuclear Medicine and Molecular Imaging)
      Neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer disease (AD) brains are composed of the microtubule-assocd. protein tau. Noninvasive monitoring of tau protein aggregates in the living brain will provide useful information regarding tau pathophysiol. in AD. However, no PET probes are currently available for selective detection of tau pathol. in AD. We have previously reported 18F-labeled THK-523 (18F-6-(2-fluoroethoxy)-2-(4-aminophenyl)quinoline) as a tau imaging radiotracer candidate for PET. After compd. optimization, we developed novel 18F-labeled arylquinoline derivs., 18F-THK-5105 and 18F-THK-5117, for use as tau imaging PET tracers. Methods: 18F-labeled compds. were prepd. from the corresponding tosylated precursors. The binding affinity of compds. to synthetic tau aggregates and tau-rich AD brain homogenates was detd. by satn. and competition binding assays. The binding selectivity of compds. to tau pathol. was evaluated by autoradiog. of AD brain sections. The pharmacokinetics of compds. were assessed in biodistribution studies in normal mice. A 14-d toxicity study with i.v. administration of compds. was performed using rats and mice. Results: In vitro binding assays demonstrated higher binding affinity of THK-5105 and THK-5117 than THK-523 to tau protein aggregates and tau-rich AD brain homogenates. Autoradiog. analyses of AD brain sections showed that these radiotracers preferentially bound to neurofibrillary tangles and neuropil threads, which colocalized with Gallyas-pos. and immunoreactive tau protein deposits. The distribution of this radiotracer binding in AD brain sections was completely different from that of 11C-Pittsburgh compd. B, showing preferential binding to amyloid plaques. Furthermore, these derivs. demonstrated abundant initial brain uptake and faster clearance in normal mice than 18F-THK-523 and other reported 18F-labeled radiotracers. THK-5105 and THK-5117 showed no toxic effects related to the administration of these compds. in mice and rats and no significant binding for various neuroreceptors, ion channels, and transporters at 1-μM concns. Conclusion: 18F-labeled THK-5105 and THK-5117 are promising candidates as PET tau imaging radiotracers.

      (18)F]T807, a novel tau positron emission tomography imaging agent for Alzheimer's disease
      Xia Chun-Fang; Arteaga Janna; Chen Gang; Gangadharmath Umesh; Gomez Luis F; Kasi Dhanalakshmi; Lam Chung; Liang Qianwa; Liu Changhui; Mocharla Vani P; Mu Fanrong; Sinha Anjana; Su Helen; Szardenings A Katrin; Walsh Joseph C; Wang Eric; Yu Chul; Zhang Wei; Zhao Tieming; Kolb Hartmuth C
      Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association (2013), 9 (6), 666-76 ISSN:.
      OBJECTIVE: We wished to develop a highly selective positron emission tomography (PET) imaging agent targeting PHF-tau in human Alzheimer's disease (AD) brains. METHODS: To screen potential tau binders, human AD brain sections were used as a source of native paired helical filament (PHF)-tau and Aβ rather than synthetic tau aggregates or Aβ fibrils generated in vitro to measure the affinity and selectivity of [(18)F]T807 to tau and Aβ. Brain uptake and biodistribution of [(18)F]T807 in mice were also tested. RESULTS: In vitro autoradiography results show that [(18)F]T807 exhibits strong binding to PHF-tau-positive human brain sections. A dissociation constant (Kd) of [(18)F]T807 (14.6 nM) was measured using brain sections from the frontal lobe of AD patients. A comparison of autoradiography and double immunohistochemical staining of PHF-tau and Aβ on adjacent sections demonstrated that [(18)F]T807 binding colocalized with immunoreactive PHF-tau pathology, but did not highlight Aβ plaques. In vivo studies in mice demonstrated that [(18)F]T807 was able to cross the blood-brain barrier and washed out quickly. CONCLUSIONS: [(18)F]T807 demonstrates high affinity and selectivity to PHF-tau as well as favorable in vivo properties, making this a promising candidate as an imaging agent for AD.
